I found a blueish glowing Crystal. After some analyses I would categorize this as an metallic semiconducting crystal.

The crystals grow, like most crystalline structures, under heat and pressure. As such, they are only found underground. Usually they form within a sandy, fertile soil, which has similar characteristics to the crystals.

Different from diamonds, the crystal structures are mostly composed of silicon, preventing them from burning at high temperatures. The melting point is 1.400°C. The materials can be refined by heating them up with a reducing agent, like carbon in form of coal or gas. By this process the crystals are transformed into handy ingots.

The neon materials work best at about 100°C. But they have a very low annealing temperature, so the most of them start to glow at around 18 - 32°C. This is a very unique characteristic and from it, I gave the name neoncrystal for the blue one I found. The world is vast; there must be more types of crystals.
